name: Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling Basics
description: Flashcards explaining key Auto Scaling group concepts and how EC2 scaling improves cost-efficiency and availability.

cards.front: You're deploying an application that must always have at least one EC2 instance running but should scale during traffic spikes. What AWS feature ensures this?
cards.back: **Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling** lets you set a minimum number of EC2 instances and scale out as demand increases, ensuring high availability.
cards.example: An app is launched with a minimum capacity of 1 and maximum capacity of 4. Auto Scaling maintains 1 instance but adds more during peak hours.
cards.subject: Scaling Amazon EC2

glossary.definition: A service that automatically adjusts the number of EC2 instances in a group based on demand.
The smallest number of EC2 instances to maintain in an Auto Scaling group at all times.

cards.front: You want to ensure your application never exceeds a specific number of EC2 instances during auto scaling. What configuration parameter handles this?
cards.back: Set the **maximum capacity** in your Auto Scaling group to restrict the total number of EC2 instances that can run concurrently.
cards.example: An Auto Scaling group with a max capacity of 4 ensures no more than 4 EC2 instances run, even during high load.
cards.subject: Scaling Amazon EC2

glossary.definition: The upper limit of EC2 instances allowed in an Auto Scaling group.

cards.front: Your traffic typically increases every weekday at 9 AM. Which Auto Scaling strategy helps you prepare EC2 instances ahead of time?
cards.back: **Predictive scaling** in Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling uses machine learning to schedule instance launches based on historical patterns.
cards.example: Predictive scaling adds instances at 8:45 AM based on observed daily traffic increases at 9 AM.
cards.subject: Scaling Amazon EC2

glossary.definition: Automatically adjusts EC2 capacity based on predicted demand using machine learning.

cards.front: Your Auto Scaling group shows a desired capacity of 2, a minimum of 1, and a max of 4. What happens during normal operation?
cards.back: Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling will maintain **2 EC2 instances** unless dynamic or predictive scaling requires scaling in or out within the min-max range.
cards.example: The desired capacity ensures 2 instances run most of the time, scaling up to 4 during spikes and never below 1.
cards.subject: Scaling Amazon EC2

glossary.definition: The number of EC2 instances that Auto Scaling tries to maintain during steady state.

cards.front: What is the primary advantage of using Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling from a cost perspective?
cards.back: **You pay only for the instances you use**, scaling in during low demand periods to reduce cost while maintaining availability during spikes.
cards.example: A video platform saves on compute costs by running 2 instances overnight and 5 during peak traffic using Auto Scaling.
cards.subject: Scaling Amazon EC2

glossary.definition: Minimizing cloud expenses by automatically scaling resources based on actual usage needs.
